2cld auth Install - Manual¶

References¶

  1. https://github.com/2cld/kerberos
  2. http://2cldkerberos.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
  3. https://web.mit.edu/kerberos/krb5-1.12/doc/admin/realm_config.html
  4. https://web.mit.edu/kerberos/krb5-latest/doc/admin/install_kdc.html
  5. https://support.ca.com/us/knowledge-base-articles.TEC1213853.html

Manual Install Steps¶

node creation¶

  1. Centos base image (with ssh) ps1
  2. ssh root@ps1
  3. Centos base image (with ssh) ctnode1
  4. ssh root@ctnode1
  5. Centos base image (with ssh) ctnode2
  6. ssh root@ctnode2

krb5-server installation¶

  1. [root@ps1 ~]# yum install krb5-server

  2. [root@ps1 ~]# vi /etc/krb5.conf

    Uncomment lines that define realm and Search and Replace with your realm name:

    :%s/example.com/2cld.lan/
:%s/EXAMPLE.COM/2CLD.LAN/

    Point kdc and admin_server to kerberos-master:

    kdc   ps1.2cld.lan
admin_server = 2cldkrv5svr.2cld.lan
  3. [root@ps1 ~]# vi /var/kerberos/krb6kdc/kdc.conf

    Search and Replace with your realm name:

    :%s/EXAMPLE.COM/2CLD.LAN/
  4. [root@ps1 ~]# vi /var/kerberos/krb6kdc/kadm5.acl

    Search and Replace with your realm name:

    :%s/EXAMPLE.COM/2CLD.LAN/
  5. [root@ps1 ~]# kdb5_util_create -s -r 2CLD.LAN

    INPUT KDC database master key: (THIS IS PASSWORD)

  6. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl enable kadmin

  7. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl enable krb5kdc

  8. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl start kadmin

  9. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl start krb5kdc

  10. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl status kadmin

  11. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl status krb5kdc

  12. [root@ps1 ~]# firewall-cmd –get-services | grep kerberos –color

    Check if kerberos service is defined in firewall

  13. [root@ps1 ~]# firewall-cmd –permanet –add-service kerberos

admin and user authentication creation¶

  1. [root@ps1 ~]# kadmin.local

    This drops us into kadmin.local shell:

    kadmin.local:  addprinc root/admin_server
Enter password for principal root/admin@2CLD.LAN: (THIS IS PASSWORD FOR PRINCIPAL)

    Add 2 client test nodes ctnode1 and ctnode2, then create keytabs:

    kadmin.local:  addprinc -randkey host/ctnode1.2cld.lan
kadmin.local:  addprinc -randkey host/ctnode2.2cld.lan
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /tmp/ctnode1.keytab host/ctnode1.2cld.lan
kadmin.local:  ktadd -k /tmp/ctnode2.keytab host/ctnode2.2cld.lan

    List principals:

    kadmin.local:  listprincs
(Confirm you see the new hosts)

    Quit out of shell:

    kadmin.local: quit

  2. [root@ps1 ~]# scp /etc/krb5.conf /tmp/ctnode1.keytab ctnode1:/tmp/

  3. [root@ps1 ~]# scp /etc/krb5.conf /tmp/ctnode2.keytab ctnode2:/tmp/

krb5_workstation installation¶

  1. [root@ctnode1 ~]# yum install pam_krb5 krb5_workstation

  2. [root@ctnode1 ~]# cp /tmp/krb5.conf /etc/

  3. [root@ctnode1 ~]# ktutil

    This drops us into ktutil shell:

    ktutil: rkt /tmp/ctnode1.keytab
ktutil: wkt /etc/krb5.keytab
ktutil: list
(should list the keytab)
ktutil: quit

  4. [root@ctnode2 ~]# yum install pam_krb5 krb5_workstation

  5. [root@ctnode2 ~]# cp /tmp/krb5.conf /etc/

  6. [root@ctnode2 ~]# ktutil

    This drops us into ktutil shell:

    ktutil: rkt /tmp/ctnode2.keytab
ktutil: wkt /etc/krb5.keytab
ktutil: list
(should list the keytab)
ktutil: quit

openldap-servers installation¶

  1. [root@ps1 ~]# yum install openldap-servers openldap-clients migrationtools

  2. [root@ps1 ~]# cp /usr/share/openldap-servers/DB_CONFIG.example /var/lib/ldap/DB_CONFIG

  3. [root@ps1 ~]# chown -R ldap. /var/lib/ldap/

  4. [root@ps1 ~]# id ldap

    Should see the ldap user id gid and groups

  5. [root@ps1 ~]# slapppasswd

    Should get a SSHA hash out, copy it

  6. [root@ps1 ~]# cd /etc/openldap/slapd.d/cnconfig

  7. [root@ps1 cn-config]# vi olcDatabase-{0}config.ldif

    Append the following to end of file:

    olcRootPW: {SSHA}longhashstringfromslappasswd
  8. [root@ps1 cn-config]# vi olcDatabase-{2}hdb.ldif

    Change the following in file:

    :%s/my-domain/2cld/
:%s/com/lan/

    So should change following (and add olcRootPW, olcAccess to bottom:

    olcSuffix: dc=2cld,dc=lan
olcRootDN: cn Manager,dc-2cld, dc-lan
olcRootPW: {SSHA}longhashstringfromslappasswd
NOW AT END OF file
olcAccess: {0}to attrs=userPassword by self write by dn.base="cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan" write by anonymous auth by * none
olcAccess: {1}to * by dn.base="cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan" write by self write by * read
  9. [root@ps1 cn-config]# vi olcDatabase-{1}monitor.ldif

    Change the following in file:

    :%s/my-domain/2cld/
:%s/com/lan/
    So should change following::

    … “cn Manager,dc 2cld,dc lan”

  10. [root@ps1 cn-config]# systemctl enable slapd

  11. [root@ps1 cn-config]# systemctl start slapd

  12. [root@ps1 cn-config]# netstat -nltp

    Should see slapd service listen on port 389, LDAPS would run on 636

  13. [root@ps1 cn-config]# firewall-cmd –get-services | grep lapd –color

    Check if lapd service is defined in firewall

  14. [root@ps1 cn-config]# firewall-cmd –permanet –add-service lapd

  15. [root@ps1 cn-config]# ls -l /etc/openldap/schema/

    Check for the schema names to import

  16. [root@ps1 cn-config]# ldapadd -Y EXTERNAL -H ldapi:/// -f /etc/opneldap/schema/cosine.ldif

  17. [root@ps1 cn-config]# ldapadd -Y EXTERNAL -H ldapi:/// -f /etc/opneldap/schema/nis.ldif

  18. [root@ps1 cn-config]# ldapadd -Y EXTERNAL -H ldapi:/// -f /etc/opneldap/schema/inetorgperson.ldif

  19. [root@ps1 cn-config]# cd

  20. [root@ps1 ~]# vi base.ldif

    Insert the following:

    dn: dc=2cld,dc=lan
objectClass: dcObject
objectClass: organization
dc: 2cld
o : 2cld

dn: ou=People,dc=2cld,dc=lan
objectClass: organizatinalUnit
ou: People

dn: ou=Group,dc=2cld,dc=lan
objectClass: organizatinalUnit
ou: Group
  21. [root@ps1 ~]# ldapadd -x -D cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan -W -F base.ldif

    Should ask for password

  22. [root@ps1 ~]# ldapsearch -x -D cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan -W -b dc=2cld,dc=lan

    Should ask for password but then get search results.

user authorization installation and creation¶

  1. [root@ps1 ~]# useradd testuser1

  2. [root@ps1 ~]# useradd testuser2

  3. [root@ps1 ~]# cd /usr/share/migrationtools/

  4. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# vi migrate_common.ph

    Set domain search for pald.com and repalce with 2cld.lan:

    $DEFAULT_MAIL_DOMAIN = "2cld.lan";
$DEFAULT_BASE = "dc=2cld,dc=lan";
$EXTENDED_SCHEMA = 1;

  5. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# grep demo /etc/passwd > /tmp/users

  6. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# grep demo /etc/group > /tmp/groups

  7. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# ./migrate_passwd.pl /tmp/users /tmp/users.ldif

  8. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# ./migrate_group.pl /tmp/groups /tmp/groups.ldif

  9. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# ldapadd -x -D cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan -W -f /tmp/groups.ldif

  10. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# ldapadd -x -D cn=Manager,dc=2cld,dc=lan -W -f /tmp/users.ldif

  11. [root@ps1 migrationtools]# cd

  12. [root@ps1 ~]# rpm -q nfs-utils

    Check if package is installed

  13. [root@ps1 ~]# yum install nfs-utils

  14. [root@ps1 ~]# vi /etc/exports

    Create exports:

    /home  *(rw,sync)

  15. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl enable rpcbind

  16. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl start rpcbind

  17. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl enable nfs-server

  18. [root@ps1 ~]# systemctl start nfs-server

  19. [root@ps1 ~]# firewall-cmd –permanent –add-service nfs

  20. [root@ps1 ~]# firewall-cmd –reload

  21. [root@ps1 ~]# showmount -e

    Should show /home * Export

ctnode1 workstation installation and configuration¶

  1. [root@ctnode1 ~]# yum install nss-pam-ldapd

  2. [root@ctnode1 ~]# authconfig-tui

    Should get config UI. Check “Use LDAP” for user info, Check “Use Kerberos” Authentication. Server: ldap://ps1.2cld.lan Base DN: dc=2cld,dc=lan

  3. [root@ctnode1 ~]# vi /etc/nsswitch.conf

    Should see ldap added to passwd, shadow and group

  4. [root@ctnode1 ~]# grep testuser1 /etc/passwd

    Should return nothing as this node does not know that user.

  5. [root@ctnode1 ~]# getent passwd testuser1

    Should see user data from ldap.

  6. [root@ctnode1 ~]# id testuser1

    Should see user data from ldap.

  7. [root@ctnode2 ~]# yum install nss-pam-ldapd

  8. [root@ctnode2 ~]# authconfig-tui

    Should get config UI. Check “Use LDAP” for user info, Check “Use Kerberos” Authentication. Server: ldap://ps1.2cld.lan Base DN: dc=2cld,dc=lan

  9. [root@ctnode1 ~]# rpm -qa | grep nfs

    Check if pakcage is installed

  10. [root@ctnode1 ~]# yum install nfs-utils autofs

  11. [root@ctnode1 ~]# vi /etc/auto.master

    Add the following to the end of the file:

    /home  /etc/auto.autofs --timeout=600
  12. [root@ctnode1 ~]# vi /etc/auto.autofs

    Create the auto.autofs file

    • ps1:/home/&
  13. [root@ctnode1 ~]# vi /etc/ssh/ssh_config

    Uncomment the following and change to yes

    GSSAPIAuthentication yes GSSAPIDelegateCredentials yes

  14. [root@ctnode1 ~]# vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

    Uncomment the following and change to yes

    GSSAPIAuthentication yes GSSAPICleanupCredentials yes

  15. [root@ctnode1 ~]# systemctl reload sshd

ctnode2 workstation installation and configuration¶

  1. [root@ctnode2 ~]# rpm -qa | grep nfs

    Check if pakcage is installed

  2. [root@ctnode2 ~]# yum install nfs-utils autofs

  3. [root@ctnode2 ~]# vi /etc/auto.master

    Add the following to the end of the file:

    /home  /etc/auto.autofs --timeout=600
  4. [root@ctnode2 ~]# vi /etc/auto.autofs

    Create the auto.autofs file

    • ps1:/home/&

  5. [root@ctnode2 ~]# systemctl enable autofs

  6. [root@ctnode2 ~]# systemctl restart autofs

  7. [root@ps1 ~]# kadmin.local

    Should put us in kadmin.local shell:

    kadmin.local: addprinc testuser1
kadmin.local: addprinc testuser2
